Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Characterization of new materials to advance separations technology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to separate and analyze a specific compound from a mixture enables scientists to make crucial discoveries that advance their science. Separations of compounds are used in all chemical and biological sciences, as well as engineering. One important technique for these separations is Electrokinetic Chromatography (EKC). This is an analytical technique that provides fast separations of minute amounts of sample through the use of an electric potential across a solution. This specific research will synthesize new materials that provide unique separation properties and improved performance within EKC. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Emily Hilder, an eminent scientist in the field of separation science at the Australian Center for Research on Separation Science (ACROSS). As one of the premier centers for separation science research in the world, ACROSS provides the infrastructure needed to demonstrate the performance of latex nanoparticles (NP), the solid substructure within the EKC separation column. This collaborative work will provide a critical step in bringing advances in EKC to the separations community.

This work will utilize advanced CE-ESI-MS instrumentation at ACROSS to achieve the high detection sensitivity required, and to demonstrate ESI interface compatibility. The NP PSPs performance will be characterized with Linear Solvation Energy Relationship (LSER) models to understand the effects of NP structure on selectivity and mobility. The LSER data will provide a fundamental understanding of the effects of NP size and chemistry on methylene selectivity and retention factors. This will provide the data needed to guide the engineering of NP PSPs for specific applications. In addition, the PSPs will be used in current research applications to illustrate NP PSP applicability to cutting edge challenges that are not addressed by existing separations technology. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Australian Academy of Science.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to separate and analyze a specific compound from a mixture enables scientists to make crucial discoveries that advance their science. Separations of compounds are used in all chemical and biological sciences, as well as engineering. One important, though less well known, technique for these separations is Electrokinetic Chromatography (EKC). This is an analytical technique that provides fast separations of minute amounts of sample through the use of an electric potential across a solution.  The potential induces an electroosmotic flow that caries the analytes through the instrument. As shown in the figure, the pseudostationary phase (PSP) is the heart of the EKC separation, controlling separation selectivity and performance, as separations are achieved through selective interactions of analytes with the PSP marked in red in the figure.

 

During this specific research, new PSP materials were characterized that provide unique separation properties and improved performance within EKC. This research was conducted in collaboration with Professor Emily Hilder, an eminent scientist in the field of separation science at the Australian Center for Research on Separation Science (ACROSS). As one of the premier centers for separation science research in the world, ACROSS provided both the expertise and the infrastructure needed to demonstrate the performance of latex nanoparticles (NP) that were used as the PSP.

 

 This work utilized Capillary Electrophoresis (CE) instruments to conduct EKC separations while Atmospheric Pressure Chemical Ionization (APCI) ionization source with Mass Spectra (MS) instrumentation was utilized for detection to demonstrate the compatibility of latex nanoparticles as PSPs with APCI-MS detection. The PSP’s performance provided an initial investigation of the effects of nanoparticle structure on the selectivity and mobility provided by the latex nanoparticles when used as a PSP. Results show that the latex nanoparticle PSPs are compatible with APCI-MS detectors while providing EKC separations of beta blockers and other small molecules that are representative of the applicability of the PSPs to cutting edge challenges in fields such as metabolomics and pharmaceutical research that are not addressed by existing separations technology. This collaborative research project provided a critical step in bringing these advances in EKC to the separations community. This work also provides data needed to guide the engineering of nanoparticle PSPs for specific applications.

 

This project has renewed the collaboration between Prof. Hilder at ACROSS and the Palmer research group at the University of Montana and introduced the PI into the collaboration. Additionally, the EAPSI Fellowship provided an outstanding opportunity to work with many of the leaders in the field of separations science and to meet with a number of the scientists who have developed some of the key techniques for characterization of the physical properties of the novel nanoparticles synthesized for this work.

 

 Beyond the opportunities for scientific and professional development, the EAPSI Fellowship also provided the opportunity for cultural exchange, both for the PI to experience the vast array of cultures represented by the researchers from around the world at ACROSS, but also to explain some of the vast and complex cultures within “the States.”

 

This NSF EAPSI award was funded in collaboration with the Australian Academy of Science. 

 

 


Last Modified: 02/28/2015
Modified by: Jesse S Hyslop

Separations of compounds are used in all chemical and biological sciences, as well as engineering. One important, though less well known, technique for these separations is Electrokinetic Chromatography (EKC). This is an analytical technique that provides fast separations of minute amounts of sample through the use of an electric potential across a solution. The potential induces an electroosmotic flow that caries the analytes through the instrument. As shown in the figure, the pseudostationary phase (PSP) is the heart of the EKC separation, controlling separation selectivity and performance, as separations are achieved through selective interactions of analytes with the PSP marked in red in the figure. During this specific research, new PSP materials were characterized that provide unique separation properties and improved performance within EKC. This research was conducted in collaboration with Professor Emily Hilder, an eminent scientist in the field of separation science at the Australian Center for Research on Separation Science (ACROSS). As one of the premier centers for separation science research in the world, ACROSS provided both the expertise and the infrastructure needed to demonstrate the performance of latex nanoparticles (NP) that were used as the PSP. This work utilized Capillary Electrophoresis (CE) instruments to conduct EKC separations while Atmospheric Pressure Chemical Ionization (APCI) ionization source with Mass Spectra (MS) instrumentation was utilized for detection to demonstrate the compatibility of latex nanoparticles as PSPs with APCI-MS detection. The PSPÆs performance provided an initial investigation of the effects of nanoparticle structure on the selectivity and mobility provided by the latex nanoparticles when used as a PSP. Results show that the latex nanoparticle PSPs are compatible with APCI-MS detectors while providing EKC separations of beta blockers and other small molecules that are representative of the applicability of the PSPs to cutting edge challenges in fields such as metabolomics and pharmaceutical research that are not addressed by existing separations technology. This collaborative research project provided a critical step in bringing these advances in EKC to the separations community. This work also provides data needed to guide the engineering of nanoparticle PSPs for specific applications. This project has renewed the collaboration between Prof. Hilder at ACROSS and the Palmer research group at the University of Montana and introduced the PI into the collaboration. Additionally, the EAPSI Fellowship provided an outstanding opportunity to work with many of the leaders in the field of separations science and to meet with a number of the scientists who have developed some of the key techniques for characterization of the physical properties of the novel nanoparticles synthesized for this work. Beyond the opportunities for scientific and professional development, the EAPSI Fellowship also provided the opportunity for cultural exchange, both for the PI to experience the vast array of cultures represented by the researchers from around the world at ACROSS, but also to explain some of the vast and complex cultures within "the States."
